tick bite. The early localized rash of Lyme disease generally occurs within the first month of infection at the site of the tick bite, often the belt line, inguinal region, popliteal fossa, or axilla. The rash expands over days to weeks, characteristically developing an area of central clearing with expansion (as seen in this patient) leading to a “bullseye” appearance. Some patients may have a small area of necrosis at the center of the rash, although this is less common.
